Response.Content: When the heart muscle contracts, it is called systole, and this action pumps blood out of the heart. This contraction happens in two stages: first the right and left atria, or upper chambers, contract simultaneously, pumping blood to the right and left ventricles or lower chambers. Then these ventricles contract together to push the blood out of the heart. Then the heart muscle relaxes, this is called diastole, before the next heartbeat. During diastole, the heart fills up with blood again. The right and left sides of the heart have specific functions. The right side of the heart collects oxygen-poor blood from the body and pumps it to the lungs, where it picks up oxygen and releases carbon dioxide. The left side of the heart collects oxygen-rich blood from the lungs and delivers it to the rest of the body so that your cells and organs have the nutrients they need to work properly.

Once your surgery date is set, your surgeon or physician's assistant is going to get you started on a number of tests. Some of them may be familiar, and you may wonder, why so many, and why take this test again?
One reason modern cardiac surgery is so effective is how much information your healthcare team has to work with before you ever enter the operating room. Your heart is imaged and mapped out in fine detail, but we also need the most complete, current picture of your overall health.
Some of the most common tests you can expect are: •Electrocardiogram or EKG to help determine the dosage of anesthesia •Urine tests to check for infections •Blood tests in case you need a transfusion, to check your kidney function, and to make sure you're not anemic. We also use these tests to check your blood sugar levels.
Other tests that you might be given include: •Carotid artery Doppler study to make sure there are no blockages in the arteries in your neck and to prevent stroke •Echocardiogram to look at how the valves are working and test the strength of your heart •Vein mapping of the legs to check for the vein that is used in bypass surgery •And pulmonary function tests to check how well your lungs are working.
If you would like to learn more about each of these tests, look in the Also Consider Asking Area.

These team members may include a respiratory therapist and a nurse from the Cardio Thoracic Intensive Care Unit, or CTICU, where you'll be recovering after surgery. You will find their expertise tremendously helpful in speeding your recovery, so think of them as your fitness coaches: the more closely you follow their instructions, the better you'll do.
You may well have heard some of their instructions before, but listen carefully anyway: first, we know we repeat ourselves, but in cardiology, repetition of safeguards is a good thing, and second, you may be given special instructions specifically meant for your particular case.
Your cardiac recovery coaches will talk with you about:

We'll be describing each of these for you as you go through the Fit for Surgery program.

To help strengthen your lungs, at your pre-operative consult, we're going to give you a plastic, handheld device called a spirometer to use every day, both before and after your surgery. It looks almost toylike, but it's a seriously effective exercise tool that fights pulmonary infections. After surgery, breathing is sometimes difficult and you might want to take only shallow breaths, which isn't good because fluid and mucus can build up in your lungs and lead to pneumonia. It's important to know how much you can help yourself: the more you exercise with the spirometer before surgery, the easier it will be to breathe afterwards.
While you're asleep during surgery, you'll be on a ventilator, so your lungs won't be inflating and emptying the way they usually do. Instead, they'll be flat, an unusual condition for them, and the tiny hairs inside your lungs called "cilia," start to stick to themselves, preventing your lungs from expanding. This is a dangerous condition called "atelectasis," (at-uh-LEK-tuh-sis) which you may know of as "collapsed lung," and it's how post-surgical patients develop pneumonia. All the more reason to practice with your spirometer before surgery. This little device will end up being one of your best friends. Your lungs will be stronger, better able to expand, and during your recovery, using the spirometer will come more easily, helping you fight off atelectasis and pneumonia.

When your surgery is scheduled, you'll be given two prescriptions. We all carry bacteria on the surface of our skin that are usually harmless, but they can enter the body during surgery, so both prescriptions are to protect you from infection while you're in the hospital.
The first, Mupirocin ointment, is an antibiotic. Put this ointment on a cotton swab and swab around the outside of your nostrils every day, starting two days before surgery, but no earlier. This antibiotic prevents infections like MRSA, which stands for Methicillin- resistant Staph Aureus. MRSA is much easier to prevent than to treat, so follow the directions you are given carefully.
Use exactly the amount you are told to use, not more and not less. Using more won't mean you get better protection. In fact, it can lessen the effectiveness of the treatment.
The other prescription is for Chlorhexidine an antiseptic shower gel that kills germs on your skin. You'll wash with this gel either the night before, or the morning of your surgery. We'll tell you more about it when we talk about the day before your surgery.
In the meantime, when you get your prescriptions, read the instructions and if you have any questions, do ask your healthcare team.

You may be surprised to hear that you'll need insulin after surgery. You may wonder, isn't insulin just for diabetics? Is heart surgery going to give me diabetes? No, but it does increase the blood sugar levels of most patients temporarily, so whether or not you are a diabetic, you will have an insulin drip before surgery and insulin injections for a short while during your recovery.
Why are we so concerned with managing your blood sugar? Because maintaining the proper level helps your sternum, or breastbone, and your incisions heal faster, and reduces the risk of postoperative infections. This is why we'll be putting you on a treatment called Insulin Drip Protocol. We use it for all of our open-heart surgery patients to manage this temporary rise in blood sugar.
You might remember that one of your preoperative tests was for blood sugar. If your sugar is high, we have you stay at the hospital the night before, and start you on the Insulin Drip Protocol then. You'll get the insulin through your IV, or intravenous line, and you'll be getting your insulin that way during surgery.
If your test shows you have normal sugar, you'll start getting insulin the morning you come in for surgery. In either case, after surgery, you'll get insulin injections, and you may need to keep taking them for a while after you go home. Most patients do, even if they're not diabetic. Keeping your blood sugar controlled is important to help you heal more quickly and avoid infections, so you'll continue to be on insulin until your doctor says you can stop.

I'm so glad to hear that. Staying away from nicotine means you're less likely to have complications and more likely to have a speedier, better recovery.

You probably know what I'm going to say, you should try to stop using all forms of tobacco or nicotine as soon as you can. We usually hear about the harm caused by smoking, but even smokeless tobacco, nicotine patches and gum, and e-cigarettes contain nicotine, a drug that can directly affect the success of your surgery.
If you can't quit smoking, try to cut down to four cigarettes a day in the two weeks before surgery.
And if you use dip, remember one can of Skoal equals four packs of cigarettes.
Nicotine users are less stable and react more unpredictably to anesthesia, so not using it for as long as you can before surgery makes a big difference.
If you're having trouble quitting, let your healthcare team know -- we can take measures that could help you.
Quitting permanently will help keep you from needing to have more heart surgery or developing other problems down the line.

It may seem to you that your surgery is a long way off right but let's start planning for your return home. You'll need someone who's able to look after you 24 hours a day.
There are a great many things you won't be able to do for a while:
•You won't be able to lift anything over 5 pounds. To put things in perspective, a gallon of milk weighs 8 pounds. •You won't be able to push or pull anything, so no pushing grocery carts, no walking the dog, no opening doors for other people. Doors will have to be pushed or pulled open for you. Even using a cane or a walker involves pushing, so if you need help walking, we'll provide you with a wheeled walker for you to use at home during your recovery. •You won't be able to lift your arms above your head, or put your hands behind your back.
If you think of the motion of a bird spreading its wings, that is exactly what we don't want you to do, for now.
Your breastbone will heal and become extremely strong in time, but for now we don't want pressure on it from any direction.
You won't be able to drive for several weeks, so you'll need someone to drive you to your follow up doctor visits until the doctor clears you to drive yourself.

As you can see, you're going to need a great deal of help for a while after you get home.
You can also help yourself heal by preparing your home for a comfortable, safe, recovery:
•Make sure you have groceries -- paper goods, and nutritious, easy-to-prepare foods. •Put chairs in strategic places so that you can do some chores from a seated position, but make sure the chairs aren't low so you don't have to push yourself out of them. •Clear the floors of obstacles and anything that could trip you -- cords, throw rugs, and toys. •If you have a cat or dog that might jump on you or weave between your legs, you may want someone else to watch your pet while you recover to prevent any accidents. •You may want grab bars installed in the shower. They're for balance, not for pulling yourself out of the bath. Towel bars aren't reliable and will not support you if you slip. •Try to make sure the everyday things you use will be reachable without stretching or bending --- put everything at counter height, not on bottom or top shelves. •A reacher/grabber is a great help as well. You can find them at drugstores, medical warehouses or online.
It's not unusual to be impatient with all the restrictions placed on you. It's much better to deal with the inconvenience of temporary limitations than to set yourself back, so I hope you'll try to be patient.

Response.BaseQuestion: Eating and drinking on the night before surgery
Response.Content:
The day before surgery, we want you to eat lightly. Stick with salads and clear broths or soup, rather than heavy meals like steak.
We tell you to eat lightly the day before surgery and have nothing after midnight because when you're in surgery, you run the risk of vomiting while you're under anesthesia.
If you vomit, you could inhale it into your lungs, which can cause serious problems like pneumonia and breathing difficulties that can seriously affect your recovery.
Another reason to eat lightly is to avoid something called ileus. Ileus is a disruption of normal bowel function. It causes cramping, bloating, diarrhea, constipation.
Nausea and vomiting are also common with ileus, which can happen if you eat a heavy meal the night before surgery, so don't eat or drink anything after midnight and that includes some things you might not think of as food such as breath mints and gum. No chewing tobacco either, and no fluids, not even water.
The only exception is if your doctor has instructed you to take any medications, and even then, take them with small sips of water. You can brush your teeth and use mouthwash, but don't swallow. The day before surgery, we want you to eat lightly. Stick with salads and clear broths or soup, rather than heavy meals like steak.

Either the night before or morning of your surgery, bathe or shower with the chlorhexidine soap that was prescribed for you. Here's how we want you to use it:
First, you're going to need a freshly laundered towel, washcloth, and a timer. You're going to begin by wetting your skin, and then you'll wash with the gel chin to ankles, using the washcloth to scrub small areas of your body at a time, including your armpits and groin, and then you're going to leave the soap on without rinsing, for five minutes, so it can do its job of killing germs on your skin.
Don't wash your face, eyes or ears with the gel because it's very strong and can irritate delicate skin. For the same reason, we want you to wash your groin, but avoid your genitals and anal area. If you feel stinging, you can rinse the stinging area with clear water. But you should leave the soap on your skin for five minutes.
Once the five minutes are up, rinse yourself thoroughly, and dry yourself with the freshly laundered towel. Put on freshly laundered clothes or sleepwear. Don't put on any deodorant, body powder or lotion. The gel has killed germs on your skin to protect you against infection, and personal cosmetics can damage its effectiveness.
Because this soap is so strong, only use it as instructed. Don't use more of it, use it more often, or use it for a longer time than your doctor ordered, and keep it out of the reach of children. Read all the precautions that come with it and call your healthcare team if you have any questions.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will they do to prepare me for surgery?
Response.Content:
Let's talk about what you can expect as you're prepped for going into the operating room. Remember your family will be there with you for as long as possible, and nurses will be with you to explain what they're doing and answer any questions you have.
First, nurses will check your pulse, blood pressure, and temperature. Then they will have you remove all jewelry, glasses, contacts, hearing aids or dentures, and they'll give them to your family or caregiver for safekeeping.
The next step doesn't hurt, but we know it isn't welcome: your body hair will be clipped from chin to ankles, including your groin. We do this to prevent infection.
Afterwards, you again wash with chlorhexidine, soap, and are given a fresh surgical gown and cap. Then it will be time for nurses to put an intravenous, or iv, line into your arm, and you will get medicine through the iv to put you into a twilight sleep so that you feel drowsy, but are not fully asleep, after which you will be taken to the or, transferred to the table, and greeted by your OR team, including your anesthesiologist.

Response.Content: Once you're on the table, you'll be given medicine through your IV line in your arm to put you to sleep. While you're asleep, your healthcare team will make the final preparations for surgery. Some of these sound uncomfortable, and it may make you uneasy to hear about them, but remember, you're asleep by now and can't feel them. Your healthcare team is highly skilled and extremely practiced at these procedures, which are necessary to make sure your surgery is successful and your recovery as smooth as possible.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What will they do to prepare me for surgery?

Response.BaseQuestion: Yes, please tell me more about how my healthcare team prepares me for surgery.
Response.Content:
OK, let me give you a short description of how your healthcare team readies you for surgery. You are going to be given a number of tubes, but let me remind you that you'll be asleep while they're being put in place.
A nurse will put an IV line into the right side of your neck so that you can get fluids before and after the operation. That IV comes out the day after your surgery.
You will also have a line that looks like an IV catheter, called an arterial line, going into the left side of your groin, so that the blood pressure in your artery can be monitored continuously.
The next tube is the Foley catheter, which goes into your bladder to empty your urine into a bag. Don't forget, you'll be asleep, and won't feel it being placed.
Because you'll have medicine to keep you still during the operation, you will need to be given a breathing tube, or intubated. The breathing tube goes down your throat, and is connected to a machine called a ventilator, which breathes for you until the anesthesia wears off and your breathing muscles are able to move again.
Depending on your doctor and the type of surgery you'll be having, you may also be put on a heart lung machine.

When your surgery is over, you'll be moved to the CTICU, where your nurse will be in the room with you, monitoring you as you come out of the anesthesia. You're going to be groggy in the beginning, but that's entirely normal.
Now I'm going to tell you something very important, that I want you to remember: you will still have the breathing tube down your throat, so you won't be able to speak or swallow, but you are safe. You may be scared and uncomfortable, but your nurse is there with you, you are not alone. Try to stay calm and remember that the nurse stays right there with you at all times, watching over you very carefully to make sure you're okay.
You'll hear sounds such as bubbling and alarms beeping. These are normal sounds made by the equipment around you. You'll also hear people talking. Someone may ask you to squeeze their hand or wiggle your toes. They may tell you that surgery is over.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Week after surgery - how are you doing?

Response.Content: We know you want that breathing tube out as soon as possible, and we do too, but you have to be fully awake first. You have to be able to hold your head off the bed for at least 10 seconds. Why 10 seconds? When you can hold your head up for 10 seconds, the nurses know that the anesthesia has begun to leave your body and you are fully able to breathe on your own. When you are ready to have the breathing tube removed, a respiratory therapist and nurse will ask you to take a deep breath and the tube will be removed. After the breathing tube is out there will be secretions in your mouth and throat, which will be removed with a suction instrument.

Response.Content:
Once the breathing tube is out the nurses wait usually about a half hour to 45 minutes before starting to give you ice chips, Your throat is going to be sore, your voice is going to be raspy, that's all normal.
Later on you will be given water. Anesthesia makes some people nauseated and sick to their stomachs, so liquids and food need to be introduced slowly. Depending on whether you're able to keep the water down, starting with breakfast the next morning you will get clear liquids and foods like jello, juice, broth and tea. Then for lunch you'll have cream soup, some pudding, maybe some ice-cream. For dinner you will have regular consistency food.

Response.Content: Another reason that food is introduced slowly after surgery is because anesthesia can also cause the bowel to stop moving. This condition is called ileus. It causes cramping, bloating, diarrhea, constipation. Nausea and vomiting are also common with ileus. Ileus can also happen if you eat a heavy meal the night before surgery.

Response.Content: Two hours after you come off the breathing machine, as long as everything's stable, you will sit up in a chair. It may seem like a lot to do so soon after surgery, but sitting up and moving around helps your lungs expand, decreasing the chance of getting pneumonia after surgery

When you come out of surgery there are a lot of tubes and wires coming out of you. As you recover over the next few days, those tubes and wires will be taken out.
Depending on your type of surgery, you will have two or three chest tubes called Blake drains. They come directly out of your chest, and are hooked up to boxes. The boxes are hooked up to suction which pulls out the old blood and fluid draining from around your heart and the space between your lung and your ribcage.
The day after surgery, the two Blake drains around your heart will come out. That one that's in that left chest space will stay in for several days.
You may or may not have temporary pacing wires in your chest. These look like pieces of thread with a blunt needle on the end. When they're not being used they are hidden in a syringe and taped to your chest. After heart surgery, you may have some irregular heartbeats. This is normal. The temporary pacing wires help to keep your heart beat stable.
After a few days a physician's assistant's will take these wires out. Removal is simple and usually doesn't hurt. the wires are out you need to stay sitting in the chair for 30 minutes while your vital signs are monitored.

Response.Content: You might think that recovery from open-heart surgery means that you'll be in bed most of the time. But getting up and getting walking after your surgery is very important. Why is that? Because walking improves circulation in your legs and prevents swelling. In the CTICU there is a section of green tile on the floor they call the path. One full lap around this path is 100 feet. Your goal, prior to discharge is 4 to 6 laps around the path, 4 to 6 times a day. So, do a lap around the time of every meal; before or after breakfast, lunch and dinner and another lap in the evening. The first time you may only do one lap, but every time you're out in the hallway try to increase your laps by one.

Response.Content:
After your open-heart surgery, your breastbone and incisions need to heal. Your surgeon uses strong closures on many layers of skin, muscle, and bone, and to insure that they knit together properly, you need to follow what are called sternal precautions. Following these precautions protects your chest and allows you to heal. So please do not hold your breath during activities, lift objects greater than 5 pounds or lift your arms above shoulder level without keeping your elbows close to your body.
Also, do not push or pull with your arms when getting up or down from a chair or bed. This is one of the most common ways people re-injure their breastbone.
Avoid any deep bending or twisting, do not use a cane or walker unless instructed by a therapist, do not repeat any activity if you feel a pulling or stretching in your chest and remember to brace your chest with a pillow when coughing and sneezing.
Your doctor will tell you when you can return to normal activities without precautions.

Response.Content:
Remember, now of all times is the time when you must focus on yourself, rather than taking care of others. If you're used to being the caretaker, it can be hard to put yourself first, but that's exactly what you need to do. You may have a hard time accepting 24-hour help the first week, too, and you may feel frustrated by the limitations on your activities, but you are laying the foundation for your post-surgery, healthy life, so accepting these temporary conditions and working with them now will prevent you from setting yourself back when you are impatient to go forward.
Your family and friends will be eager to visit, and they can be great mood-lifters, but for the first week you're going to be tired, so you should limit how many of them visit you at a time to 2 or 3, and keep the length of their visits to a half hour. Ask your caregiver to run interference for you if you have a hard time saying no. Above all, focus on getting the rest and gentle exercise you need for your recuperation.
Now let's talk about the daily activities you can do to speed it along.

The first week that you're home you should be doing some basic things every day.
•Get a shower every day - remember, no tub baths, swimming or hot tubs for 6 weeks. •This is a good time to do a daily check of your incision in front of the mirror. •Check your incisions for any signs of infection (swelling, warmth, fever, redness, pain). •Weigh yourself daily - you need to contact the doctor if you gain more than 2 pounds in a day. •Balance rest with daily activity. •Rest with legs elevated four times daily, above the level of the heart. •Avoid sleeping during the day if you find that you are not sleeping at night. •Stay active. •Get up and get dressed every day. •And, remember good hand washing, especially before touching your incision.

•Do not lift anything over 5 pounds. •No driving until cleared by your surgeon. •No pushing or pulling with your arms. •No lifting your arms above your head or behind your back. •And no sexual intercourse until cleared by your surgeon.
Along with these restrictions, remember that if you have been in the habit of using tobacco before your surgery, you must stop using all forms of tobacco. As you know, smoking and other tobacco use is a major contributor to heart disease. All tobacco contains nicotine, which narrows the blood vessels, causing your blood pressure and heart rate to increase and damaging organs. Quitting all tobacco use will help your recovery and keep you from having to have more heart surgery and other health problems in the future. Your healthcare providers can help you quit if you find that you're not able to stay away from tobacco use on your own.

You may be concerned about your incision coming open. Your healthcare team is very experienced and has taken every step to make sure that it won't.
Your incision has several lay First, your sternum, or breastbone is wired so that the two halves of the bone will grow back together. Then there are three layers of stiches to keep your muscles and skin closed so that they can heal as well. As a final precaution, medical glue is used to hold the top layer of your skin closed. This glue will flake off on its own over time. Your incision is sturdy and as long as you follow the sternal precautions and restrictions that we talked about you should not have any problems with your incision.
However, you should take good care of your incision so let's go over it in more detail. •Inspect your incision in the mirror every day and look for signs of infection. It is normal to have some redness, itching and soreness around your incision, but it should get a little better every day. If it becomes redder, or there is drainage or pus, call your doctor immediately. •Leave your incision open to air. Do not put bandages over your incision. Women may use gauze under their bra to prevent rubbing. •Wash your hands with soap and water before touching your incision. •Shower daily and wash your incision with mild soap and water. Avoid soaps with perfume because they can irritate your incisions. •Also, don't stand in the direct spray of the shower. Instead, stand with you back to the spray and let the water wash over your chest. •Pat your incision dry with a freshly laundered towel each day, do not reuse your towels. •Do not use any ointments, creams powders or lotions on your scar. •Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a hot tub or spa for 6 weeks.

Response.Content: Angina is pain caused by the heart muscle not receiving enough blood. When the heart pulses to push clean, oxygenated blood out to the rest of the body, a small amount of blood is diverted directly to the heart muscle. If this blood supply is compromised due to heart disease in the coronary arteries -- the main arteries that lead directly to the heart muscle -- angina can occur. Muscle spasms of the heart may alone be responsible for angina, but is a quite rare.

A heart attack occurs when blood flow to a part of your heart is blocked for a long enough time that part of the heart muscle is damaged or dies. This also called a myocardial infarction. Most heart attacks are caused by a blood clot that blocks one of the coronary arteries. The coronary arteries bring blood and oxygen to the heart. If the blood flow is blocked, the heart is starved of oxygen and heart cells die. A heart attack may also occur if not enough oxygen-rich blood can flow through a partial blockage. This is more likely to happen when your body is stressed by physical demands or emotions, however most often occur from midnight to 10 AM without exertion.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are symptoms of a heart attack?
Response.Content:
What are the symptoms of a heart attack?
The symptoms of a heart attack include: •Chest pain or discomfort (like pressure, fullness or squeezing) •Discomfort in the upper body (either arm, back, neck, jaw or stomach) •Shortness of breath •Cold sweats •Nausea •Sudden or extreme fatigue not related to lack of sleep.
These symptoms can come and go, and they can be different in each person. Women more often experience different symptoms than men. The reason that heart attack symptoms are sometime hard to diagnose is because the heart itself does not feel pain. The symptoms of heart attack are due to the nerves leading from the heart causing other nerves to short circuit, leading to pain, nausea, cold sweat and other symptoms. However, sometimes you may not have any pain at all, which is why people sometimes have no idea that they are experiencing a heart attack. This is one reason why it is so important to have your heart checked out and to assess your risk factors for heart disease. If you experience any symptoms, please seek help immediately.

Angina is often described as "chest pain" but this can be misleading. Angina is not always painful, and it isn't always felt in the chest. Angina might feel like this:
•Discomfort, aching, tightness or pressure that comes and goes. You may feel this in your chest, back, abdomen, arm, shoulder, neck or jaw. •More fatigue than usual for no clear reason. •Shortness of breath while doing something that used to be easy. •Heartburn, indigestion, nausea, or sweating.

Angina usually happens during activity. It can also occur when you're upset or after a large meal. If angina starts occurring more frequently, lasts longer or causes more discomfort, you may have unstable angina. It's a sign that your heart problem may be getting worse.

Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries as the heart pumps blood. If this pressure rises and stays high over time, it is called high blood pressure or hypertension and it can damage the body in many ways. High blood pressure leads to heart disease, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and other health problems. About 1 in 3 adults in the United States has HBP. Knowing your blood pressure numbers is important, even when you're feeling good. Blood pressure is measured as systolic, or contracting, and diastolic, or releasing and filling, pressures. You most often will see blood pressure numbers written with the systolic number above or before the diastolic number, such as 120/80. Both systolic and diastolic blood pressure measures are important.

An arrhythmia is an irregularity with the rate or rhythm of the heartbeat. During an arrhythmia, the heart can beat too fast, too slow, or with an irregular rhythm. A heartbeat that is too fast, greater than 100 beats per minute, is called tachycardia. A heartbeat that is too slow, less than 60 beats per minute, is called bradycardia. Most arrhythmias are harmless, but some can be serious or even life threatening. During an arrhythmia, the heart may not be able to pump enough blood to the body. Lack of blood flow can damage the brain, heart, and other organs. Arrhythmias can be genetic, or be caused by other illnesses such as thyroid disease. It's important to note that every heart experiences arrhythmia every day, usually a very small percentage of the 100,000 beats per day in normal hearts, and most often it goes away.

Plaque that accumulates on the inner walls of your arteries is made from the calcium, fat, cholesterol, cellular waste, and fibrin in your blood. As this plaque builds up, cells in your artery walls secrete other substances that can increase the build-up even more. And, as plaque deposits grow, the arteries narrow and harden, this is called atherosclerosis.

A stroke happens when blood flow to a part of the brain stops. This can be caused either by blockage of a vein or artery leading to the brain by a blood clot called ischemic stroke, or by rupture of a blood vessel, called a hemorrhagic stroke. If blood flow to the brain is stopped for longer than a few seconds it deprives the cells of blood and oxygen causing cell death and permanent damage.
Stenosis is the abnormal narrowing of a blood vessel, such as an artery or a valve, and can be caused by atherosclerosis and other heart disease including calcium buildup or it may be congenital.
An angiogram is a special X-ray of a blood vessel.
The aorta is the body's largest artery. It carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body.
An artery is a blood vessel that carried blood from the heart to the body.
The atria are the heart's two upper chambers. They receive blood from the lungs and body.
A balloon angioplasty is a procedure that uses a balloon-tipped catheter to open an artery narrowed or blocked by plaque.
Blood serum cholesterol is a fatty substance produced by the body and carried in the blood. It can build up within artery walls as plaque.
Blood vessels are tubes that carry blood throughout the body. Arteries and veins are blood vessels. Bypass provides a new pathway for blood flow.
CABG is another term for coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
Cardiomyopathy is the weakening of or structural change in the heart muscle that reduces the heart's ability to pump.
A catheter is a long thin flexible plastic tube.
Coronary arteries are blood vessels that wrap around the heart and supply the heart muscle with oxygen-rich blood.

Coronary artery disease or CAD is a narrowing of the small blood vessels that supply blood and oxygen to the heart. It is often called coronary heart disease. The coronary arteries bring blood and oxygen to your heart. Over time fatty materials like cholesterol and other substances form a plaque build-up on the walls of the arteries. This buildup causes the arteries to become narrower. As a result, blood flow to the heart can slow down or stop. This can damage the heart muscle and other organs as well. CTA can identify these plaques even before they calcify.
Diastolic pressure is the pressure of blood between heartbeats. It appears as the bottom number in a blood pressure measurement.
A myocardial infarction is the death of heart muscle tissue. It is also known as a heart attack.
The pulmonary artery is the large artery that carries blood from the heart to the lungs to get oxygen.
Systolic pressure is the pressure of the blood against the inside of artery walls during a heartbeat, when the heart pumps. It appears as the top number in a blood pressure measurement.
An ultrasound is a test that uses sound waves to create images of structures inside the body.
Valves are doorways that open and close to let blood move are prevent backflow of blood. There are valves between the hearts chambers.
A vein is a blood vessel that carries blood from the body back to the heart.
Ventricles are the heart's two lower chambers. They pump blood to the body and lungs.

An echocardiogram produces an image of your heart, but it does so with sound waves; no radiation exposure is required. This commonly used test allows your doctor to see how your heart is beating and pumping blood.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is vein mapping of legs?
Response.Content: If you're having bypass surgery, you will need an ultrasound of the greater saphenous vein in your leg. This procedure is performed to create a "map" of your leg veins for the surgeon. The greater saphenous vein is one of the veins that will be used to bypass the blockages in the arteries leading to your heart, and doctors need to know where the vein is located.

Pulmonary function tests are a group of tests that measure how well your lungs work. This includes how well you are able to breathe and how well your lungs are able to supply oxygen to the rest of your body. The pulmonary function test will be done bedside before you go into surgery.

An electrocardiogram (or EKG) is a test that checks for problems with the electrical activity of your heart. Your body's natural electrical system is what signals the heart muscle to contract and pump blood from the heart to the lungs and the rest of the body. An EKG produces a picture of the heart's electrical activity. This picture of the heart's electrical activity can tell us how the heart rhythm is functioning.

A urine test is done to make sure you don't have any infections in your bladder or urinary tract. Hidden infections such as these can cause complications after surgery. If you're having bypass surgery you will provide a sample by urinating into a specimen cup. However, if you're having valve surgery, a clean urine sample is needed. That means that a nurse or trained technician will need to do a straight cath, or catheter.

You've probably had blood drawn before. Even though you may have had blood work done recently, there are blood tests that need to be done closer to your surgery. Before cardiac surgery your blood is drawn to check your blood sugar and kidney function.

A chest X-ray uses a very small amount of radiation to produce an image of the heart, lungs, and chest bones. With an x-ray, doctors can see the structures of the chest and look at where devices such as pacemakers and defibrillators are placed. They can also diagnose lung and cardiac disease. To have a chest x-ray taken, you will be asked to stand very still with your chest against the area that contains the film plate. The x-ray machine will then send a beam of ionizing radiation through your chest which is absorbed on film to create a picture. You will be asked to hold your breath for a few seconds to generate better images by reducing motion. Then you will be asked to do the same thing, but with your left side against the film plate and your arms elevated.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a carotid artery Doppler study?
Response.Content: A carotid artery Doppler study is a painless test which shows whether your carotid arteries, the arteries in your neck, are blocked by plaque. If there are blockages in your carotid arteries there is a greater risk of stroke during your surgery. This test involves putting a small amount of gel on your neck and rolling a wand, called a transducer, over the arteries.

Knowing that you have a heart problem you may wonder how you can improve your health. Cardiac rehabilitation or cardiac rehab is a program designed by your healthcare team that not only helps you recover, but also reduces your risk for future heart problems.
Your cardiac rehab program may begin while you're in the hospital. After you're discharged you may go to a special facility for scheduled rehab classes. Once you regain some strength and learn how to exercise safely, your doctor may prescribe an exercise program for you to follow at a fitness center or at home.

Response.BaseQuestion: How to use an incentive spirometer
Response.Content:
The location of your incision makes it hard to take deep breaths. So you will use an incentive spirometer for your deep breathing exercises. This device will enable you to take those very important deeper breaths. You need to use the spirometer every hour, each time taking 10 deep breaths. It may hurt at first, but with adequate pain medication, you will be able to make progress each time you use it.
This is how it works. •You place your mouth over the mouthpiece of the unit. •Then take a slow, deep breath in. •Hold that breath. •Then slowly release the breath out.

After open heart surgery, especially valve surgery, you are at increased risk for a condition called Endocarditis. This is an infection in the heart that can travel to other parts of the body and cause a wide variety of very serious problems. Because of this, you should not get body piercings or tattoos after you have had open heart surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: Whatís the role of a Physician Assistant?
Response.Content: The role of a physician assistant (or PA), especially in cardiac surgery, is just an extension of the surgeon. We're a very important part of the surgical team, itself. You'll see us before and after surgery; we'll be involved in your care the whole way along. We also are involved in the operating room. We assist the surgeon in surgery: we also have certain parts of the surgery that we do ourselves. We can write you prescriptions and answer all of your questions before and after surgery and any time in between.

Response.BaseQuestion: The importance of showering with Chlorhexidine
Response.Content: The chlorhexidine that you're going to be given before surgery is an important part of the routine prior to surgery. It's basically just like an anti-bacterial soap like Dial but a little bit stronger. There are important instructions that you are going to need to read when you get the bottle from the pharmacy. You'll be given a script for it; you're going to take that to your pharmacy, and I want you to read all of the instructions because they're very important. When you use the chlorhexidine, you need to get into the shower and get wet. You need to scrub from your chin down, everywhere, and you're going to scrub for five minutes--you're going to have the water turned off at that point. After you scrub for five minutes, you're going to turn the water back on, and you need to rinse off completely. We don't want any soapy residue on you anymore. But it's a very important part because it helps prevent a bacteria load on your skin prior to surgery where we're going to be cutting.

MRSA is called a "Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus." We all have bacteria on our skin, and we all typically have a staph aureus on our skin. But MRSA is a resistant bacteria, and it's resistant to the typical antibiotics that treat staph. It's a very risky infection if you do get it. Some of the reasons why we give you the chlorhexidine (and you'll later hear about mupirocin) is to try and prevent MRSA infections specifically.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why canít I have anything to eat or drink after midnight?
Response.Content: We don't like you to eat or drink anything after midnight before surgery because if food or drink is in your stomach or in your intestines there's a risk it could come back once the anesthesia is given--it could come back up the wrong way and get into your lungs or cause other types of problems. So we like to make sure that everything is empty before any medication is given, especially if you're going to be in such a deep sleep for surgery.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Eating and drinking on the night before surgery
What kind of meal should I have the night before surgery?

Response.BaseQuestion: What kind of meal should I have the night before surgery?
Response.Content: The day before surgery, we don't want you to have anything very heavy: no steaks or meats. You can eat things like soup, light meals. And that's very important because the anesthesia you're going to be given with surgery slows down your gut motility in your intestines and can increase your issues with things like constipation after surgery and not having a bowel movement which can cause serious issues.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is most important thing I can do before surgery?
Response.Content: The most important thing I tell my patients before surgery is to just try to relax. I know that there's a lot of anxiety with having a major surgery, especially open heart surgery, but it's very important to try and relax, enjoy your time with your family the day before, and that's really going to help you get through the surgery well and will help your chances for recovery afterwards. If you need anything to help you, you can always call one of the physician assistants or surgeons, and we can prescribe a medication if you're having tremendous anxiety prior to surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does it really matter if I quit smoking before surgery?
Response.Content: If you quit smoking before surgery, it really will have an impact on your overall hospital course and how quickly you will recover. A lot of studies have shown that if you quit for as little as ten days before surgery, you do a lot better than if you smoke up until the day of surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: How long will it take for my breastbone to knit?
Response.Content: After surgery, we have to cut your breastbone to get to your heart during surgery. Afterwards, we put wires in around your breastbone. It's like any other broken bone except we can't cast it, so we put wires in to help heal it. Your bone starts to gain about 75% to 100% of its strength back by about six weeks after surgery, and it should be 100% strong by about two months after surgery. Okay, with open heart surgery you're going to have an incision down the front part of your chest. It will be a fairly long incision, but it's going to heal nicely. Usually the incision heals within about two months of surgery and will continue to heal after that, and you will just notice a white line afterwards. You've probably seen people who have had open heart surgery that have incisions like that, and you will have the same kind of incision.

Response.BaseQuestion: How common is it to experience depression after surgery, and what are some of the signs?
Response.Content: After surgery, you might feel at times that you're sad or tearful or having symptoms of depression. About 25% of open heart surgery patients actually experience that, so it's fairly common and is nothing to be ashamed of. You need to tell someone right away when you start to feel signs like that--when you're very, very sad or you feel hopeless because we can start you on a medication that takes some time to actually take effect--but we can start you on a medication for that if you like. Or we can get you some counseling help or reassure you that the feelings you have are normal.

Response.BaseQuestion: The anesthetist is present and monitoring during surgery
Response.Content: You will see an anesthesiologist before your surgery, typically the morning that you come in for surgery. You're going to see a lot of different people; you will see a nurse, and then you'll be able to see the nurse anesthetist as well as the anesthesiologist who will talk to you about putting you to sleep for the surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: The closures are more than just stitches
Response.Content: With open heart surgery, the way that we have to get to your heart is that we have to make a cut down the center of your chest. We do cut through your breastbone, which is the bone in front of your heart, to get to the heart to do the operation. We put stainless steel wires around your breastbone to bring it back together after surgery. You will have three layers of stitches on top of that. You will also have a skin glue or a skin sealant just as an added protection.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the most common causes of post op sternal problems?
Response.Content: So, after surgery, in order to protect your breastbone we want to make sure you don't push yourself out of a chair. A lot of times after surgery, you're feeling really weak, you may try to put your arms on the chair and push yourself up which is bad because it puts a lot of tension on the breastbone. Rather, it would be best if you just rock forward, maybe a couple of times, and eventually you'll have enough momentum to be able to stand up on your own.

Response.BaseQuestion: What does a PA do after surgery?
Response.Content: After surgery you're going to see a physician assistant every day. We're going to be pulling drains and lines, we will answer all of your questions, if you need any prescriptions filled or refilled we can fill those for you and write them, we can fill out any disability paper for you, and one of the most important visits you're going to have after surgery when you leave the hospital is the one-week appointment with one of the physician assistants.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there any side effects from anesthesia? If so, what should I expect?
Response.Content:
Everyone acts differently to anesthesia. It's hard to pinpoint how someone is going to wake up from anesthesia and any lingering effects afterwards. Some people wake up very calmly and do not have any problems with that time frame.
Some people wake up like a bear, kind of moving their arms around knowing that something is different. The nurse is with you here the whole time to reassure you, calm you, to let you know that everything is okay you've have made it through your surgery and now you're in your recovery phase. Sometimes it creates some nausea but we have medication to help prevent the nausea from occurring.

We're very strict on hand hygiene. When we bring our family members back to see the patients, we advise them from the beginning to use the hand sanitizer that is located right outside of the unit. But we also let them know that there are hand sanitizer stations located throughout the unit and within in the patient's room along with sinks. We don't want you bringing germs in here, and when you leave we want you to do the same thing because we don't want you taking germs out with you.
If you feel comfortable, please let staff, the doctors, whomever, know or ask them if they used the hand sanitizer. If you don't feel comfortable with it, then let your nurse know. But you should see them wash their hands or use the hand sanitizer.

We perform rounds essentially Monday through Friday, they are more formal at that time, at 9am. If physician, the surgeon is not in the operating room with another case then he will be present for those rounds. And some of the other people within the interdisciplinary team would be the physician assistant, a bedside nurse, charge nurse, a dietician then some ancillary staff like social worker or case manager would follow up with us later in that time. But we advise the family to be involved with these rounds at least a couple times during the week; that way you keep abreast of the progress with your loved one. Because we begin discharge planning the day they come into the hospital. We want to know what is going to be the safe, realistic way for them to leave here, whether it be at their home, rehab, or to a facility.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why can't I drive for a few weeks after surgery?
Response.Content: The surgeons don't want you driving for 4 weeks after you have your heart surgery for a couple of reasons. Your sternum, which they cut through, is still very fragile and you're limited to a lot of different activities because of that. Speaking to not driving if you would (a) be in a car accident and jolted forward then your sternum is at risk for being injured and not healing the right way. Another thing is that you're still very tender in the chest area and you're not going to be able to turn a lot to look over your shoulders. So those are two of reasons you can't drive. We don't advise you sitting in the front seat either in case of being in an accident; and if the air bag would deploy and hit your chest, then your sternum is still at risk for not healing appropriately.

I am standing in one of the CTICU rooms at Forbes Regional Hospital. There are 8 beds in our CTICU unit. Each room is equipped with a toilet and shower to provide your own privacy. This is where we try to keep you through the duration of your hospitalization, so this is where you come right after surgery and this is where you recover.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is it like waking up from surgery?
Response.Content:
When you wake up from surgery you will still have a tube down your throat, which is helping you breath. Some people aren't bothered by it at all, and some people have used the analogy that it feels is like that there is a straw, and they are breathing through a straw. We need to emphasize as nurses that you need to be as calm as you can, because as much as the uncomfortableness of this breathing tube is, the more you are fidgety and chew on it the longer you will have it in.
It is very scary, but we do our job to get that breathing tube out within 5 hours from the time you come to the room after your heart surgery. So, if you come out of the operating room at 1pm, by 5pm we want to get that breathing tube out.
In regards to the breathing tube there are certain things we are going to need you to do before it can come out of your mouth. To be awake enough to do a few things such as squeezing our hands wiggling your toes and lifting your head up off your pillow to show you have good power over your nerves more to say. To let us know you are going to be able to breath on your own once that tube comes out.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will make life easier during recovery?
Response.Content:
To ensure you have the best recovery period there are a few things the nurses will be reminding you of, not only for here in hospital but for once you go home: coughing, deep breathing, and the use of your incentive spirometer.
So the coughing and deep breathing and the use of your incentive spirometer help to expand your lungs and prevent pneumonia, which is one of most common post op problems after heart surgery. The other one is to get up and walk. We start that here while at the hospital and encourage that once you go home. That helps circulate your blood and prevent blood clots from forming.

In regards to your pain, everyone has different pain levels. Some people have very little or no pain at all. Some people have pain that they've never thought they'd have before. Most of the pain is in the incisional area. However, sometimes people complain of pain off to the center of the incision, which is caused by a drain. It sits kind of in your lung cavity in a pleural space to help drain blood that is not circulating. But sometimes from taking that deep breath, that causes more pain than the actual incision does.
So while you're here during first 24 hours, we will generally give you some IV medication. We do note your allergies in case you have things you cannot take, and we will start you on oral pain medication. If these medications do not work for you, we call the physician and we let them know you are still having a lot of pain, because we want you to be comfortable.
We're not going to give you something that is going to take your pain away completely at first. Over time your pain will get less and less, and you'll that see you'll be requiring less medications for pain as your recovery goes on. I will say that men usually have a little bit more pain because of their musculature across their chest and there are more muscle that doctors have to cut into. So men generally experience more pain than women do.

Response.BaseQuestion: What kind of clothing should I bring?
Response.Content:
During your recovery in the CTICU you will be dressed in a hospital gown and if you choose you can also wear a pair of hospital bottoms. For those who have sensitive feet you may want to bring a pair of slippers that are not snug because sometimes you develop some swelling and you will be walking on a hard floor. While you're here, just the hospital gown and bottoms.
For your discharge you will want to bring something comfortable, loose probably nothing with a tight waist band because sometimes you still hold onto a lot of fluid your swollen and you'll just need something that fits comfortably for your time home. Your shoes should probably be something you slid into as I said you still have some swelling a lot of times and it would be difficult to get your foot into a hard shoe or something that ties.

Our visiting times here in the CTICU are from 9am until 9 pm we do not let children under the age of 10 come into visit for many reasons. One it's overwhelming to see and hear things that are not usual for them and we don't want them to bring in any germs and we don't want them to pick up any here while they are visiting.
We do not allow any food to be brought in and no flowers or plants. If they're delivered we usually keep them at the nurses' station. There is a chance they can bring in bugs and we don't allow those in our unit.
If you feel inclined to send something balloons are a nice touch or just a phone call would be nice.

During your time in CTICU in your recovery phase you will be on insulin. Insulin helps the body to heal after having surgery. Not only heart surgery but other surgeries as well, so don't be alarmed when the nurse and doctor let you know you are receiving insulin.

Response.BaseQuestion: Constipation and the importance of a bowel movement
Response.Content: One of the side effects of having anesthesia and pain medication can be constipation and no one likes to talk about that, but we ask you not to eat or drink anything after midnight the night before your surgery. With that being said we don't advise having a heavy meal that day either so eating something light. Constipation is a problem we follow a certain bowel regiment here during your post op period in the hospital. We view constipation as a big problem. Anesthesia, pain medication, not moving around like you usually do, not eating the foods you usually eat can all contribute to constipation. So we'll be asking you a lot if you're passing gas, if you've moved your bowels and we're just here to get those bowels moving.

Response.BaseQuestion: Incision care and drainage - what to expect to see in your incision
Response.Content: It's not unusual to see a little bit of drainage coming from the incision as long as it's a small amount, and as long as it's not anything like pus. Sometimes you may even see a small little bit of the suture come out because the body does not always absorb it and rather spits it out instead.

Response.BaseQuestion: Pain medications, addiction concerns and preventing pneumonia
Response.Content: After surgery, you might have issues with pain. We will have a lot of different types of pain medication we can give you. I do not want you to be concerned that you're going to get addicted to this pain medicine; within the short period of time that we're treating you, you will not become addicted to the pain medicine. It is extremely important for you not to be in so much pain, especially when you're taking deep breaths because we don't want you to get pneumonia. If you are guarding and not taking deep breaths because you don't want to take pain medicine, you are more likely to get pneumonia, and that's a very bad thing after surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: How to check for signs of infection
Response.Content: After surgery, and especially when you go home, it's very important to take good care of your surgical incisions. If you notice any drainage, redness, or warmth of the areas of your incision you need to call us immediately so that we can see you in the office and take care of any issues.

Response.BaseQuestion: The importance of walking around after surgery
Response.Content: After surgery, since you have sternal precautions, and you're not allowed to do much with your arms if anything, walking is the best activity that you can do. We encourage you to walk, especially around the mall if you can get somebody to drive you there. Walking around the mall, especially when it's cold weather, is one of the best things. If it's nice, warm weather you can walk outside. We do caution you because we do not want you to do anything with your arms, so you are not going to be able to walk your dog outside.
